questions.text: Which of the following cancers is not protective by use of combined oral contraceptives? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Breast cancer

 

Combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) provide protection against several types of cancers through their hormonal effects. This protective effect can be remembered using the mnemonic "CEO" - Colorectal, Endometrial, and Ovarian cancers. However, OCPs are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer and possibly cervical cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometrial cancer: Incorrect. OCPs are protective against endometrial cancer due to the progesterone component which counteracts unopposed estrogen effects on the endometrium.

 

Option C. Colorectal cancer: Incorrect. OCPs provide protection against colorectal cancer through their hormonal mechanisms.

 

Option D. Ovarian cancer: Incorrect. OCPs significantly reduce the risk of ovarian cancer by suppressing ovulation and reducing the repetitive damage to ovarian epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCPs provide protection against three types of cancers (CEO - Colorectal, Endometrial, and Ovarian) but increase the risk of breast cancer and potentially cervical cancer.

questions.text: Identify the sign. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Double ring sign

 

The image shows a radiograph with a distinct double ring appearance, which is characteristic of a button battery. A button battery has a three-dimensional structure with two concentric rings when viewed on X-ray, creating the "double ring sign." This appearance is diagnostic of a button battery, a common foreign object seen in pediatric radiographs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. String sign: The string sign refers to a thin, string-like narrowing often associated with conditions like Crohn's disease or hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. It does not have the double ring appearance seen in this image.

 

Option C. Bird beak sign: The bird beak sign is associated with achalasia and appears as a tapering of the distal esophagus resembling a bird's beak. This sign does not resemble the double ring pattern shown in the image.

 

Option D. Double bubble sign: This sign is associated with duodenal atresia and appears as two bubbles (the stomach and the proximal duodenum) on an X-ray. It is distinct from the double ring pattern seen with a button battery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "double ring sign" on an X-ray is characteristic of a button battery, easily distinguishable by its unique appearance.

questions.text: The extra layer of skin found in the epidermis of the palms and soles is: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stratum Lucidum.

 

  • Stratum lucidum is the extra layer of epidermis that is specifically located over palms and soles. 
  • This layer is characterized by its translucency (lucidum refers to translucency) and contains Eleidin granules. 
  • The stratum lucidum is positioned between the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum in the epidermal layers of palms and soles.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stratum Corneum:

 

  • This is the outermost layer of the epidermis, not an extra layer. 
  • It is present in all skin areas and consists of anucleate, fully keratinized flat cells forming the dead protective layer.

 

Option B. Stratum Granulosum:

 

  • This layer contains keratohyaline granules and lamellar granules (Odland bodies). 
  • It is present throughout the epidermis and is not an extra layer specific to palms and soles.

 

Option D. Stratum Spinosum:

 

  • Also known as the prickle cell layer, this contains polygonal keratinocytes connected by desmosomes.
  • It appears beneath the stratum granulosum throughout the epidermis and is not an additional layer specific to palms and soles.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The stratum lucidum is a distinct translucent epidermal layer found exclusively on palms and soles, positioned between the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum, containing eleidin granules.

questions.text: Multiple Lisch nodules is a feature of? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are small, benign (non-cancerous) hamartomas of the iris, which are melanocytic in nature. They are a common clinical feature of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple non-cancerous tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas) and pigmented spots on the skin (café-au-lait spots). Lisch nodules are typically asymptomatic and are detected during an ophthalmic examination. They are considered pathognomonic for NF1, meaning their presence strongly suggests the diagnosis of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This is a genetic disorder that causes non-malignant tumors to form in many different organs, primarily the brain, eyes, heart, kidneys, skin, and lungs. However, it is not associated with Lisch nodules. Instead, it involves other skin manifestations like angiofibromas and Shagreen patches.

 

Option C. Leprosy: Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, primarily affecting the skin, peripheral nerves, upper respiratory tract, and eyes. It does not involve Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, particularly the lungs and lymph glands. It is characterized by the formation of granulomas—small clumps of inflammatory cells. Lisch nodules are not a feature of sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lisch nodules are a characteristic feature of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and are important in the diagnosis of this genetic disorder.

questions.text: Entry of glucose is insulin independent in all of them except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Adipose tissues

 

Glucose enters cells through GLUT (glucose transporter) proteins. Some are insulin-dependent, while others are not.

 

Adipose tissues:
•    Use GLUT4
•    Insulin-dependent
•    Insulin stimulates translocation of GLUT4 to membrane → increases glucose uptake

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. RBC (Red Blood Cells)
•    Use GLUT1
•    Insulin-independent

 

Option B. Pancreas (β-cells)
•    Use GLUT2
•    Insulin-independent
•    Glucose entry triggers insulin secretion

 

Option D. Brain
•    Uses GLUT1 (BBB) and GLUT3 (neurons)
•    Both are insulin-independent
•    Brain requires a constant glucose supply regardless of insulin


 

Educational Objective:

 

Major Glucose transporters and their function is summarized as:

questions.text: What is the purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Adolescents

 

Explanation

 

The HEADSS assessment is a structured psychosocial interview technique specifically designed to be used with adolescents. The purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation is to provide a comprehensive framework for obtaining a detailed history from adolescents. It covers several key areas, including:

 

  1. Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home.
  2. Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status.
  3. Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time.
  4. Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use.
  5. Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors.
  6. Suicide/Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.

 

Now Extended to become – HEEADSS

 

E – Eating and Exercise

 

S - Safety

 

Educational objective: 

 

The HEADSS assessment helps healthcare providers establish rapport with adolescent patients, identify risk factors, and discuss sensitive issues in a non-judgmental, confidential manner. This can lead to better health outcomes by addressing potential problems early.

questions.text: The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6th cranial nerve

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This can be remembered using the" This means that the Superior Oblique muscle is innervated by the 4th cranial nerve, the Lateral Rectus by the 6th cranial nerve, and the rest of the extraocular muscles are innervated by the 3rd cranial nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, but not the lateral rectus.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 4th cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) innervates only the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option D. 7th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) is not involved in eye movement; it primarily controls facial muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve).

questions.text: A patient with dyspnea, respiratory distress due to pan-acinar emphysema, and liver dysfunction is due to a likely defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency

 

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency of the alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein, which protects the lungs from neutrophil elastase.

 

This deficiency leads to the development of pan-acinar emphysema, especially in the lower lobes of the lungs, and liver dysfunction, such as cirrhosis, due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha 1 anti-trypsin in hepatocytes.

 

The combination of pulmonary and hepatic manifestations, particularly pan-acinar emphysema, is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A gene: Mutations in this gene are associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism, leading to systemic copper deficiency. It does not cause emphysema or liver dysfunction seen in alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency.

 

Option B. ATP7B gene: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, which affects copper metabolism, leading to liver disease and neurological symptoms but not emphysema.

 

Option D. Surfactant defect: Surfactant deficiency typically occurs in preterm infants, leading to respiratory distress syndrome due to immature lung development. It does not cause emphysema or liver dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is associated with pan-acinar emphysema and liver dysfunction due to a deficiency of the protective alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein.

questions.text: Detoxification of Xenobiotics for phase 1 reaction (Hydroxylation) require monooxygenase/cytochrome P-450 along with: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADPH

 

The detoxification of xenobiotics in phase 1 reactions, particularly hydroxylation reactions catalyzed by monooxygenases or cytochrome P-450 enzymes, requires reducing equivalents in the form of NADPH. NADPH serves as a cofactor that provides electrons for the enzymatic reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NADH: NADH is not the primary cofactor used in phase 1 hydroxylation reactions.

 

Option C. FAD: FAD (Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide) is not typically involved in the hydroxylation reactions of xenobiotic detoxification in phase 1.

 

Option D. FADH2: Similar to FAD, FADH2 is not the primary cofactor required for the hydroxylation reactions involved in the detoxification of xenobiotics during phase 1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this reaction, a xenobiotic undergoes hydroxylation with the help of oxygen and NADPH as a cofactor. The cytochrome P450 enzyme catalyzes this reaction, leading to the introduction of a hydroxyl group into the xenobiotic molecule, making it more water-soluble and facilitating subsequent conjugation reactions in phase 2 detoxification.

questions.text: Which of the following does not pass through the sinus of Morgagni? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: d. Stylopharyngeus

 

 

Explanation:

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle does not pass through the sinus of Morgagni. Instead, it passes through the gap between the superior and middle constrictors of the pharynx. The stylopharyngeus arises from the styloid process and passes downwards between these constrictors to run on the inner surface of the pharyngeal wall.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Auditory tube - The auditory tube (Eustachian tube) does pass through the sinus of Morgagni, which is the large gap between the upper concave border of the superior constrictor and the base of the skull. This semilunar gap is closed by the pharyngobasilar fascia.

 

Option B. Levator veli palatini - This muscle passes through the sinus of Morgagni. It enters the pharynx by passing over the upper concave margin of the superior constrictor, runs downwards and medially, and spreads out in the soft palate.

Option C. Ascending palatine artery - This artery passes through the sinus of Morgagni. It's a branch of the facial artery that ascends between the styloglossus and stylopharyngeus muscles and passes through the sinus to reach the soft palate.

 

Education Objective:

 

The sinus of Morgagni is a gap between the superior constrictor muscle and the base of the skull that allows passage of the auditory tube, levator veli palatini muscle, and ascending palatine artery—but not the stylopharyngeus muscle, which passes between the superior and middle constrictors.

choices.text: Concentration of K+ is greater in ECF
Concentration of Cl– is greater in ICF
Total ions are more in ICF

questions.text: As a result of the Donnan-Gibbs effect, which of the following is true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Total ions are more in ICF

 

Explanation:


The Donnan-Gibbs effect describes the unequal distribution of ions across a semipermeable membrane when one ion (typically charged proteins) cannot cross the membrane. In cells, the non-diffusible ions are primarily the negatively charged proteins (Prot-) trapped inside. This creates an electrical imbalance that affects the distribution of all permeable ions, ultimately resulting in more total osmotically active particles (ions) inside the cell than outside. This ion imbalance contributes to the osmotic pressure that would make cells swell and potentially rupture if not counterbalanced by the Na, K ATPase pump.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Concentration of K+ is greater in ECF - This is false. K+ concentration is significantly higher in the intracellular fluid (approximately 140 mEq/L) compared to extracellular fluid (approximately 4.5 mEq/L). The Donnan effect actually contributes to this concentration difference.
  • Option b. Concentration of Cl– is greater in ICF - Cl- is higher in ECF than in ICF, it is not the primary consequence of the Donnan-Gibbs effect. The key result is the overall ionic imbalance with more total ions in ICF.
  • Option d. All are true - This cannot be correct since option a is false.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Donnan-Gibbs equilibrium results in an asymmetric distribution of ions across cell membranes with more total ions accumulating in the intracellular compartment due to the presence of non-diffusible, negatively charged proteins.

questions.text: Tracheal innermost layer has which epithelial lining? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified columnar epithelium

 

The trachea, or windpipe, is lined with a specific type of epithelium designed to protect and facilitate the movement of mucus. The innermost layer of the trachea consists of pseudostratified columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium appears to have multiple layers (strata) because the cells' nuclei are at different levels, giving a false impression of stratification (hence "pseudo"). However, it is actually a single layer of cells.

 

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium primarily consists of tall, column-like cells that are closely packed together. Despite appearing layered due to the varying positions of the nuclei, it is a single layer of cells. This structure is crucial for the trachea as it often contains cilia (tiny hair-like projections) and goblet cells that produce mucus. The cilia help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, aiding in keeping the airways clear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous epithelium: This type of epithelium consists of flat, thin cells and is usually found in areas where rapid diffusion or filtration is required, such as the alveoli in the lungs. It is not suitable for the trachea, which needs a more robust lining to handle mucus and cilia.

 

Option B. Ciliary epithelium: While the pseudostratified columnar epithelium in the trachea does contain ciliated cells, "ciliary epithelium" itself is not a distinct classification of epithelial tissue. Therefore, this option is incorrect as a type of epithelial lining.

 

Option D. Cuboidal epithelium: This type of epithelium consists of cube-shaped cells and is generally found in glandular tissues or ducts (like kidney tubules). It is not found lining the trachea, as it lacks the specialized structure needed for mucus movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The innermost layer of the trachea is lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium, which appears layered due to the positioning of cell nuclei but is actually a single layer of cells designed to protect the respiratory tract and facilitate mucus movement.

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The patient presents with signs of an acute epidural hematoma (EDH), as evidenced by the biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on the CT scan, along with a deteriorating Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15. An epidural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency, especially when accompanied by neuro deterioration, as in this case. The immediate next step is decompression, which involves relieving the pressure on the brain by surgically removing the hematoma. This procedure can be done through a burr hole or craniotomy and is crucial to prevent further brain injury or death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Mannitol: Although IV mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, it is not the definitive treatment for an acute EDH with neuro deterioration. Mannitol may be used temporarily to manage intracranial pressure, but it does not address the underlying cause of the pressure, which is the hematoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This approach is inappropriate in this scenario due to the immediate threat posed by the hematoma. Delaying treatment could lead to irreversible brain damage or death.

 

Option D. Anticoagulation: Administering anticoagulation would exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient’s condition. It is contraindicated in the setting of an active intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural hematoma with neuro deterioration is a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate decompression to prevent further brain injury and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Instilling a particular idea in people’s mind and not affecting their thought process is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Health Propaganda

 

Health propaganda is a method of communication aimed at instilling a particular idea or belief in people's minds without engaging their thought process. Unlike health education, which appeals to reason and encourages reflective thinking and skill development, health propaganda is more emotion-driven and does not foster independent thought or critical analysis. The objective is to influence behavior quickly and effectively, often without the support of scientific evidence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Health Awareness: This involves disseminating information to make people aware of health issues, but it does not necessarily instil a specific idea nor does it bypass the thought process.

 

Option C. Health Education: Health education involves a reasoned approach where individuals are informed and encouraged to think critically about health-related issues. It promotes reflective behavior and skill development.

 

Option D. Health Promotion: This is a broader concept that encompasses health education and activities aimed at improving overall health, but it does not specifically focus on instilling ideas without thought.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Health Education versus Propaganda/Publicity

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient suffers with extracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intramedullary nailing

 

INTRAMEDULLARY NAILING

 

  • Intramedullary Nailing is a surgical technique used to stabilize fractures by inserting a metal rod (nail) into the medullary canal of the bone.
  • Mechanism: The nail is inserted into the central canal of the femur and fixed with screws at the ends to stabilize the fracture.

 

 

  • It is generally used for femoral shaft fractures but can be applied to extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly.
  • Indications: Intramedullary nailing is effective for stabilizing long bone fractures and can be used for femoral neck fractures if the fracture pattern and bone quality are suitable.
  • Complications: There is a risk of complications including infection, nonunion, and poor functional outcomes if not done properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Russell’s Traction: Russell’s Traction is a type of skeletal traction used to align and stabilize fractures, particularly in the lower extremities. This traction method involves applying a pulling force to the limb through a system of pulleys and weights. It can help in aligning fractured bones and reducing pain by immobilizing the affected limb. For elderly patients with extracapsular femoral neck fractures, Russell’s traction is less preferred due to delayed recovery as the traction does not allow early weight-bearing or mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to prevent complications like pressure sores and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The immobilization provided by traction alone might not adequately stabilize the fracture, leading to a higher risk of nonunion or malunion. Prolonged use of traction can lead to muscle atrophy and joint stiffness.

 

 

Option B. Bar and Boot Plaster: Bar and Boot Plaster is a type of external immobilization used for fractures, particularly in the lower limb. This involves applying a plaster cast to immobilize the fractured limb, often including a bar and boot to provide additional support and alignment. It is used for fractures where conservative management is appropriate, particularly in pediatric or less complex cases. For extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients, this method is generally not preferred due to inadequate stabilization. Prolonged immobilization can lead to complications such as muscle atrophy, joint stiffness, and pressure sores, especially in elderly patients who are already at high risk for these issues.

 

 

Option D. Hemiarthroplasty: Hemiarthroplasty involves replacing the damaged femoral head with a prosthetic component while leaving the acetabulum intact. It is often used to address both the fracture and any pre-existing joint degeneration. Hemiarthroplasty is often preferred for intracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to immediate stability provided to the hip joint and allowance for earlier weight-bearing and mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to reduce the risk of complications from prolonged immobility. The prosthesis can alleviate pain and improve functional outcomes compared to conservative management methods. The procedure has risks such as dislocation, infection, and prosthesis failure, but it generally provides better outcomes in terms of mobility and quality of life for elderly patients compared to non-surgical methods.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing, while useful for certain types of fractures, is generally the first choice for extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to the risks and potential complications associated with the procedure.
  • Cephalomedullary nailing is done in such cases.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of rivaroxaban is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xa inhibitor

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that works by inhibiting Factor Xa, a crucial enzyme in the blood coagulation cascade. The name "rivaroxaban" itself hints at its mechanism of action, where "Xa" refers to Factor Xa, and "ban" suggests inhibition. By inhibiting Factor Xa, rivaroxaban prevents the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, thus reducing the formation of fibrin clots. This inhibition is crucial in preventing and treating conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and reducing the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation.

 

Other Xa blocker drugs: Apixaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IIa inhibitor: IIa refers to thrombin (Factor IIa), and while inhibiting thrombin is another anticoagulation strategy, rivaroxaban does not act on Factor IIa. Instead, drugs like dabigatran work as direct thrombin inhibitors.

 

Option C. Vitamin K antagonist: This refers to a different class of anticoagulants, such as warfarin, which inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Rivaroxaban does not affect vitamin K or its associated pathways.

 

Option D. Antithrombin activation: Antithrombin activation is the mechanism of action for drugs like heparin. Rivaroxaban does not work by activating antithrombin but rather by directly inhibiting Factor Xa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is a direct, reversible inhibitor of Factor Xa, a key enzyme in the blood coagulation process, and is used as an anticoagulant.

questions.text: A newborn presented with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Any of the above

 

Occult spinal dysraphism is a condition where there is a defect in the fusion of midline embryonic neural, vertebral, and mesenchymal structures, and it can be presented in newborns with a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region. Typically, patients with occult spinal dysraphism have a cutaneous abnormality overlying the lower spine, such as a small dimple, a tuft of hair, or a subcutaneous lipoma. These abnormalities can be a sign of underlying spinal cord abnormalities, and it's important to evaluate them thoroughly to rule out any serious underlying conditions.

 

Spinal dysraphism includes-

 

Open spinal dysraphism: Myelomeningocele, meningocele

Occult spinal dysraphism:

  • Spina bifida occulta
  • Spinal lipoma
  • Dermal sinus
  • Tethered cord
  • Split cord malformation (diastematomyelia)
  • And others
     

 

 

 

The initial investigation is usually ultrasound in the neonate and the best investigation is MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region in a newborn may indicate occult spinal dysraphism, which includes conditions such as spina bifida occulta, spinal lipoma, and dermal sinus, all of which can be signs of underlying spinal abnormalities requiring thorough evaluation, typically starting with ultrasound and definitive imaging with MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Kwashiorkor is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: D. All Skin and Bone Appearance

 

Explanation: 

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition primarily due to protein deficiency while maintaining relatively adequate caloric intake. The "all skin and bone appearance" is characteristic of marasmus, not kwashiorkor. Children with kwashiorkor typically have edema that masks the muscle wasting, giving them a falsely "plump" appearance. They have a distended abdomen, edema (especially of the feet and legs), and fatty liver due to decreased lipoprotein production and transport.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Moaning Cry - This is a true feature of kwashiorkor. Children with kwashiorkor often have a characteristic plaintive, moaning cry due to general irritability and weakness.

 

Option B. Red-Haired Boy - This is a true feature. Kwashiorkor causes depigmentation of hair, leading to reddish or yellowish discoloration (flag sign), particularly noticeable in children with naturally dark hair.

 

Option C. Mosaic Dermatitis - This is a true feature of kwashiorkor. Also called "flaky paint dermatosis," the skin develops patches that crack and peel, particularly in areas exposed to repeated friction or pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, red/blonde hair discoloration, irritability, and mosaic dermatosis, while the "all skin and bone" appearance is typical of marasmus due to calorie deficiency with relative sparing of protein.

choices.text: Fear of places from which escape is difficult

questions.text: All of the following may be termed as Agoraphobia, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Fear of heights

 

Explanation: 

 

Agoraphobia is specifically defined as fear of places from which escape might be difficult. The fear of heights (acrophobia) is a specific phobia and not a component of agoraphobia. Agoraphobia includes fears related to situations where escape might be challenging, embarrassing, or help may not be available if panic-like symptoms occur.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Fear of places from where escape is difficult (Incorrect): This is the core definition of agoraphobia. People with agoraphobia fear situations where they feel trapped, helpless, or embarrassed.
  • Option C. Fear of open spaces (Incorrect): This is included in the definition of agoraphobia. 
  • Option D. Fear of crowded places (Incorrect): Fear of crowded places is a characteristic manifestation of agoraphobia. Crowded places may trigger anxiety due to perceived difficulty in escaping or reaching help if needed.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Agoraphobia is characterized by fear of situations where escape might be difficult, help might not be available, or where panic attacks might occur. It commonly includes fears of open spaces, enclosed places, crowds, public transportation, and being outside alone. Specific phobias like acrophobia (fear of heights) are distinct from agoraphobia and classified separately as specific phobias.

questions.text: Which ion is most responsible for the resting membrane potential (RMP): (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) K+

 

The resting membrane potential (RMP) of a cell is primarily determined by the distribution of ions across the cell membrane and the relative permeability of the membrane to those ions. Potassium ions (K+) play the most significant role in establishing the RMP. This is because the cell membrane is more permeable to K+ ions compared to other ions, and there is a higher concentration of K+ inside the cell than outside.

 

The movement of K+ out of the cell down its concentration gradient leads to a negative charge inside the cell relative to the outside. This difference in charge across the membrane is what we refer to as the RMP. Other ions, such as sodium (Na+), calcium (Ca2+), and chloride (Cl-), have some influence, but their impact is much less compared to K+.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ca2+: Calcium ions have a much smaller role in setting the RMP. They are more involved in processes like muscle contraction and neurotransmitter release rather than in establishing the RMP.

 

Option C. Na+: Sodium ions have a minimal direct role in determining the RMP under normal conditions because the cell membrane is much less permeable to Na+ at rest compared to K+. The Na+/K+ pump helps maintain the gradient of Na+ and K+, but Na+ itself does not significantly influence the RMP.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions can influence the RMP, but their effect is secondary to that of K+. Since the membrane is more permeable to K+, the RMP is predominantly a result of K+ distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resting membrane potential is primarily determined by the concentration gradient of potassium ions (K+) across the cell membrane and the membrane's permeability to K+.

questions.text: Which glucose transporter is primarily affected in diabetes mellitus? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. GLUT-4

 

Explanation:


GLUT-4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter predominantly found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. In normal physiology, insulin stimulates the translocation of GLUT-4 containing vesicles from intracellular compartments to the plasma membrane, facilitating glucose uptake. In diabetes mellitus, insulin resistance or deficiency disrupts this translocation process, significantly reducing glucose uptake in insulin-sensitive tissues, which contributes to hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. GLUT-2: This bidirectional, low-affinity glucose transporter is primarily found in pancreatic β-cells, liver, intestine, and kidneys. While GLUT-2 function in β-cells is important for glucose sensing, it's not the primary transporter affected in the pathophysiology of diabetes.
  • Option b. GLUT-5: This transporter primarily facilitates fructose transport rather than glucose and is mainly expressed in the small intestine. It plays a minimal role in diabetes pathophysiology.
  • Option d. SGLT-2: This sodium-glucose cotransporter is located in the proximal tubule of the kidney and mediates glucose reabsorption. While SGLT-2 inhibitors are used in diabetes treatment, the transporter itself is not primarily dysfunctional in diabetes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Diabetes mellitus fundamentally affects insulin-mediated glucose disposal, with GLUT-4 dysfunction representing the critical link between insulin resistance and hyperglycemia as its translocation from intracellular vesicles to the plasma membrane is impaired, preventing efficient glucose uptake in muscle and fat tissues.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations over the past two months. Laboratory tests reveal decreased TSH and elevated T3 and T4 levels. She is started on iodine-131 therapy. What is the most common long-term side effect of this treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothyroidism

 

Explanation:

 

I-131 (radioactive iodine) therapy is commonly used for hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease). The most common long-term side effect is hypothyroidism, due to:

 

  • Destruction of thyroid tissue
  • Permanent reduction in thyroid hormone production

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism relapse: Rare, as radioactive iodine typically leads to permanent thyroid destruction

 

Option B. Thyroid storm: Acute complication, not a long-term effect

 

Option D. Radiation-induced thyroiditis: Can occur but is a transient complication

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism is the most common long-term side effect of radioactive iodine (I-131) therapy, requiring lifelong thyroid hormone replacement.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

 

The pharyngeal constrictor muscles are organized into three main parts: the superior, middle, and inferior constrictors. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the mechanics of swallowing and speech.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passes between the superior and middle constrictor muscles. This is a key anatomical relationship to remember as it is crucial for the nerve supply to the pharynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube: Passes through the sinus of Morgagni, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option C. Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option D. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

questions.text: What is the term for a primary skin lesion that is flat, without elevation or depression, and less than 1 cm in diameter? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Macule

 

  • A macule is a circumscribed, flat lesion of skin that is visible because of a change in skin color. 

 

 

  • It is neither elevated nor depressed, has no change in skin texture, and by definition is less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Macules can be hyperpigmented (like fixed drug eruption), hypopigmented (like leprosy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papule 

 

  • A papule is a small, solid, elevated lesion less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Unlike macules, papules project above the skin surface and 

 

Option C. Patch 

 

  • A patch is similar to a macule in that it is flat and has a color change, but by definition, a patch is larger than 1 cm in diameter. 

 

Option D. Vesicle 

 

  • A vesicle is a fluid-filled, circumscribed, elevated lesion less than 1 cm in diameter. 
  • Vesicles form due to a split in the skin and contain clear fluid.

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • A macule is a flat, non-palpable, circumscribed lesion less than 1 cm in diameter that represents a change in skin color without alteration in skin texture or thickness.

questions.text: The Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing which of the following conditions? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute severe ulcerative colitis

 

The Truelove and Witt criteria are specifically used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis. These criteria help classify the disease into mild, moderate, or severe categories.


Another set of criteria called the Travis criteria is used to assess treatment response and predict the risk of progression to surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Encephalitis: Incorrect because encephalitis has its own specific diagnostic criteria and severity assessment tools that focus on neurological symptoms and findings.

 

Option C. ARDS: Incorrect because ARDS is diagnosed and classified using the Berlin criteria (2012), which primarily use the P/F ratio (PaO2/FiO2) with a PEEP of at least 5 cm H2O.

 

Option D. Acute pancreatitis: Incorrect because acute pancreatitis has scoring systems for severity assessment, such as Ranson's criteria or the APACHE II score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Truelove and Witt criteria are used for assessing the severity of ulcerative colitis.

 

Truelove and Witt's Criteria for Severity of Ulcerative Colitis
